commentBody: This puzzle has me laughing, the solves are wonderfully silly, thanks to the constructor!
Well, that was fun! Got the theme, filled it in, so thanks for a fun few minutes!

1. Sotto VOCE in da house!  Again!

2. Someone asked last Tuesday if there was really more than one ARK.  I didn't reply then because the clue mentioned boats, like the one Noah built.  But certainly there are ARKS, as this clue reminds us...in every synagogue, the ARK is where the Torahs are kept.

3. I had WINGS for AISLE and was wondering why it should be plural.  The answer, is, OBVI, that it isn't.

4. Since my wife took up GOLF in her 60's, I, who have no interest whatsoever, have taken to quoting Twain on the matter repeatedly.

5. I don't think DOLLY Parton ever wastes time.

6. 44A: Only middle schoolers?

7. 14A: "Trigonometry" is spelled out; no abbreviations!

8. 64D:  How old do you have to be?

To Barry, left over from the Monday puzzle:  Simms has two Super Bowl rings, but he did not win two Super Bowls.  The win goes to the starting quarterback, even if he is injured on the first play.  Simms did not play in the Buffalo Super Bowl, so the claim is more than tenuous, and should have been written differently.

Thinking, perhaps, *you‚Äôd* rather not have a repeat of last week‚Äôs attention, I‚Äôll skip any comments on 12D. üòÇ

A fun fast Tuesday. Bing, bang, boom. I liked it a lot, Kathy Lowden.
Solved in 8:25 with no peeks. Getting good at this!!
Those were delightful! Made me laugh. Thanks, Kathy!

This was almost 40 minutes faster than my average and no lookups. Pretty good for a beginner! 

That being said, I understood the theme immediately which helped with crossed I wouldn't have known. Without that I may have struggled a bit more. 

What a delightful start to my day. Thanks, Kathy!
This was fun!  And loved the Mark Twain quote - I hadn‚Äôt heard that one before and I agree!
Ding dong dang! Adorable! As the world‚Äôs biggest dilly-dallyer, I‚Äôm delighted that I got through it so hastily! Obvi, I‚Äôm all lit up!

Regarding 44 across, this brings out the 12 year old in so many of us. I got a much needed giggle recently from a WaPo headline stating "Uranus may have been misunderstood for nearly 40 years."

Showed it to a friend who was feeling down from the bombardment of election news and it was the best laugh he'd had in weeks. 

Fun puzzle.

Fun theme but I first tried ‚Äúsandal scandal‚Äù but it didn‚Äôt fit.

@sam corbin, I think Twain means GOLF is so frustrating that it becomes a spoiled walk. I find golf anything but monotonous! I‚Äôll feel ready for the LPGA on one hole and then ready for the ‚Äú19th hole‚Äù on the next.

Parting thought: It‚Äôs often a good idea when someone OBEYS unless it is in advance.

Boas festas! üéÅ

Sigh, lost another written comment because of the Times' really primitive and ephemeral JavaScript forum implementation.

So I'll just say I enjoyed this fun little puzzle and theme despite a few nits, including the strange "obvi" instead of "obvs".  Nice job.


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Some nice amusing evening entertainment. Thanks, Kathy!

A silly but amusing puzzle that incorporates ablaut reduplication. https://www.rd.com/article/ablaut-reduplication/ And another shout-out to my friend in the Pacific Northwest. Thanks for the fun, Ms. Lowden!

Real fun! Very clever wordplay. 
Not difficult at all, but rewarding withal.

Once I had the "E" for prey of gray wolves, I honestly hoped that it would be EMU those wolves had a taste for, and not ELK. But alas, we must rely on the dingo dogs to pare down the mob of emus. Yes, you read that right: a group of emus is called a mob of emus. 

Lively and interesting Tuesday, brought me straight back to high school (I was the NERD who called my pencils "styli"), with its obsession with goop and acne, exlax and Uranus (what a pair!), and lack of desire to learn anything of "sine" and "alkali." 

Confused goat on the loose?
WILLYNILLY BILLY

Noisy nuns every Sunday?
MISSES MESSES MASSES

Also admired the elgant ascending vertical trio of LLs in the SW corner, but thought OBVI quite strained. Interesting to have the unusual CAVA a few days ago and also arcane KAVA. 

Australian tennis star adores pate de foie gras?
LIVER LOVER LAVER

Angry con man gets in your face?
FLIM FLAM PHLEGM

(I know, that last one...)

Yes, I'm honored to have a handle that has gotten me in the NYT puzzle already twice. As they say, if you're in the NYT crossword, you've finally arrived. üòÇ

But the reason I'm dropping in is to say how impressed I am by this puzzle. It's not just Ms. Lowden's creativity; it's all those K's she braved for crosses, daring to go where no one has dared to go before. 

The fill tripped me up a bit, here and there, so I can't say I breezed through like your usual Tuesday, but still it was a fresh grid that I very much enjoyed.

Thank you, Ms. Lowden!

P.S. Gosh, I love me some Mark Twain witticisms!

Another terrific Tuesday.
Thanx Kathy.

Some expression contains both "mean" and "lean"?

Did I know it once?
That was a really fun theme in a thoroughly enjoyable puzzle. It's almost as if the editors are trying to make up for that messy Sunday grid ü§£
ŒüœÖœÅŒ±ŒΩœåœÇ isn‚Äôt pronounced the way you think it is. üòÉ

There was a string of comments on the Monday puzzle that were about cheating.  I find the concept of cheating on the NYTimes puzzles to be weird.  Why do you work the puzzles?  Is it some sort of self affirmation that you have the brains and breadth of knowledge to do them? that you are trying to keep your mind clicking away to avoid getting rusty? that you are hoping to prove yourself superior to other solvers,? or are you simply enjoying a diversion? Whatever the reason, "cheating" cannot be cheating if there's no one to cheat. Cheating implies that there will be some advantage to be gained by doing it, and there isn't any here.  The whole concept is ridiculous.

I  set a standard for myself in the Bee never to try to find words except those in my own memory, or that can be made using prefixes or suffixes to devise some I don't actually know, and I do google sometimes for spelling. Otherwise, I'm on my own, because at my age I can't afford to lose any ground.  The words are there, and the challenge is to find them. But for the crosswords, I enjoy researching clues for answers, learning new things, and I have never considered it "cheating."  

It would be sad to think that we are here trying to fight it out to prove who is the smartest kid on the block. That will never work, because how could we prove it to people we have never met and will very likely never see?

We can enjoy being together without sneering at solvers who choose to work a puzzle in their own way.

My first thought for "kerfuffle over beach footwear" was SANDALSCANDAL which didn't fit but I'm still pretty proud of it. 

Fun theme. I got stuck with an E making HASTE/LACE instead of HASTY/LACY so that completely ruined my time but a good puzzle nonetheless.
The fun continues, a perfect Tuesday puzzle that had me smiling throughout, can‚Äôt ask for more than that.
Classifying LIME as an Alkali is a bit of a stretch though, isn't it?

Fun puzzle. Typical slow start for me, but a great 'aha' moment when I finally caught on to the trick and then it all came together pretty smoothly.

Drifting... was actually within sight of LAOS a couple of times at one point in my life. That led me in a roundabout way to wonder about HOCHIMINHTRAIL as a possible answer. But I miscounted - thought it was 15 letters but it's 14. Anyway - HOCHIMINH was an answer in one puzzle, though HOCHIMINHTRAIL is in the Xword Info word lists. 

And... of course had a couple of puzzle finds today. Might put those in replies. 

...

Having joined the chorus of those with qualms about Sunday‚Äôs puzzle I feel obligated to praise Tuesday‚Äôs, which exemplifies what I enjoy most about puzzles.  Subtle, thoughtful wordplay is what it‚Äôs all about for me and this puzzle rings the bell.

A healthy helping of fun with a side of
Sotto Voce!

Perfect.

The world has been feeling heavy and this was
a very welcome, whimsical oasis.

Thank you Kathy!
Can a puzzle be adorable? Because this one is. After an IFFY Sunday that had me feeling a little BLUE, Monday and today's puzzles have me LIT UP.

Since my earlier post never came through, I guess I'm not allowed to say the word for rear end that begins with bu and ends with tt. Oh, well, I'll leave that part out and repost the rest. Silly Tuesday fun. Thanks for the smiles, Kathy. The perfect introduction to the DILLY DALLY song: https://youtu.be/UkctTHDxa38?si=wGWooVgwJpLYzsWa

I really enjoyed this puzzle. All the themers were great.

I'm on my way to Ottawa today. HASTY reminded me of the chain of Hasty Markets there. Maybe Ontarians are used to the name, but I always imagine them as stores where you make unwise (or maybe just careless) decisions as to what to eat for supper.

I don't usually share YT videos when commenting on NYT puzzles...but when I do they're Leroy Anderson tunes. https://youtu.be/xhOZbmeA-t0?si=t3psJZbh0_uBPGg2 I thought I was a goner on this this one, but click-clank-clunk it all fell into place. Sailed through the rest of it like Anderson's "Sleigh Ride" https://youtu.be/E30TjigZXpE?si=ncFa6JxsIKzPiMQv Perfect for this time of year!

Solved more than 10 minutes faster than my average today! Love the theme! I got them all relatively quickly. 

Question: is it always sotto VOCE? I thought it was sotto voice. Maybe I‚Äôm just mentally adding the ‚Äúi‚Äù?
nice quick one and i really enjoyed the themed clues today! very fun!

I make so many mistakes typing answers into my iPad,

but I just keypad it.

(haven‚Äôt tried styli)
It's not just middle schoolers.....I'm 52 and I still snortle at times.

Chef's tip: for really elegant tea sandwiches,
CRISS-CROSS CRESS
On the other had, the economical cook will toss whatever's at hand into their polenta:
MISH-MASH MUSH

When. let's face it, you're really, really old, but still up on the music of today:
HIP-HOP HEP.

And, (OK, this is quite a stretch, but I like the image), my samoyed is good at 80's arcade games, because she's a

DIG-DUG DOG,

First time commenter, not a long time crossworder, but I just have to say how much I enjoyed the theme today!
Once I figured out that first one, I was excited to get the rest of
Yep, thoroughly enjoyed it -- good way to ease into the day.

"NaOH and KOH" for 5D and "Na+ and K+" for 6D might have appealed to a chemistry NERD. Along with "Litmus paper color for 5D" for 61D. OK, probably not.

Not much of a theme, but cute enough and no stolen artwork was involved.
Maybe later after I stop smiling.
Why have you dropped the Constructor comments?

Why would middle schoolers laugh at URANUS? URANUS is majestic. URANUS is giant and gaseous. Granted, URANUS has a weird ring around it. But URANUS deserves respect!

--Katie, age 37

No spoilers, plz, until we're past "view all replies".

Strands #289
‚ÄúIt's lit!‚Äù
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üü°üîµ

I'm not fond of the spangram, awkward and not necessary.

Once I knew it was going to be KNICKKNACK, the KNOCK went right in too.  At which point I jumped to all the other theme clues to see if I could get them with few to no crosses.

I already had the 2nd P in FLIP FLOP FLAP and that answer went right in.  PING PONG PANG and DILLY DALLY DOLLY went in with no crosses.

The rest of the puzzle was anticlimactic but I filled it in anyway.

Very well chosen themers.  I can't think of any other possibilities  -- can you?  I also like how aptly and succinctly each of them is clued.  A breezy,  playful theme.  Here's one I'd give to a newbie solver:  Very easy, but also very entertaining and a nice intro to the fun one can have with wordplay-infused crossword puzzles.

Is Proactiv the name of a yoghurt anywhere outside the UK? Gave me pause to be told it treated ACNE when I solved it from the crosses.
Or was that just a deliberate bit of misdirecting ambiguity for US solvers, too?
I take offense to 44A. I‚Äôm not in middle school!

KNIC-  was all it took.
That's not a Brag; I was a bit disappointed that I didn't need to hesitate or consider options...  
At least, not unti 61D, where I glimpsed the word 'rainbow'  and already had the B from LABOR in place.
First?  What about ROY G. BIV?  I was about to have PANGs (speaking of LABOR) when I saw 'alphabetically'.  Whew

Bryllcreem, bah.
I miss the BURMASHAVE signs that relieved the long pre-interstate-highway trips across the continental US of A.

I wonder if I had known that a horror columnist (see Wordplay) would become a thing if that would have changed my path in life.  As a youngster I was very into that genre, having been raised on Frankenstein, Dracula, the Werewolf, the Mummy, Twilight Zone, Alfred Hitchcock, Thriller Theater (who remembers that one?) and Outer Limits.  Oh well, perhaps the next life.

That was fun! And very clever.

In my haste, I erred with LAC-Y, and had to resort to the answer key. Willy nilly silly.

Silly Tuesday fun. Thanks for the smiles, Kathy. It's the perfect introduction to the DILLY DALLY song: https://youtu.be/UkctTHDxa38?si=wGWooVgwJpLYzsWa Really though, enough about poor URANUS, always the butt of jokes.

Bongo bongo bongo, I don't wanna leave the Congo, 
Oh no, no, no, no, no,
Bingle bangle bongle, I don't wanna leave the jungle,
I refuse to go.
A sweet puzzle! Very enjoyable. I‚Äôll be checking out that Halloween puzzle!

I've spent a good bit of my life teaching Greek mythology and the three generations of Gods, each with their respective kings:  Ouranos, Kronos, and Zeus.  There is a power and beauty to the stories of Ouranos, the Sky, who mates with Gaia, the Earth, to produce the next generation of Gods, the Titans.

And then it all falls apart when the students start giggling about Uranus.

What are you going to do?  There is a little 12-year-old inside of all of our heads.

Such a fun Tuesday puzzle! The wordplay was a great start to the day. 

My first (non-alliterative) thought for the last theme entry was some combination of Dolly, folly, and another -olly, which would be really fun in a puzzle too!
A quick and fun puzzle!

Coriolanus isn't usually taught until college, but I can guarantee you it still gets laughs.

Started out with KNICKKNACK craCK but quickly adjusted via the crosses, and the rest of the themers fell pretty easily with a delightful bing, bang, bong. Nice to have a breezy Tuesday.
Not to be anal about it, but the Id's counterpart is the SUPEREGO, not the EGO.

[Way of getting around on social media?]

Whimsically enjoyable theme.

I've tried to maintain my neutrality in the wars of plurality, but now you've gone too far, tiger. The only proper plural of Al Kaline is Al Kalines.

Said no one ever, "Check out my baseball card collection-I've got all the AL KALIS."

That'd be like saying, "Some of my paintings have been stolen! Where are my Picassae?"


TIKTOK TUK-TUK
Tee-hee

I felt very smart for getting FLIP FLOP FLAP (and thus the theme) with only the starting F - so much fun!

However I take issue with the implications of 44a - URANUS is certainly still funny to many grown adults :-)

Clue 33 led me down a rabbit hole (when was golf popularized outside Scotland? When was Twain writing?) but after some research, I think I can say with reasonable confidence, that Mark Twain did not say that golf was a good walk spoiled. Here's a good article discussing the history of that quote: https://quoteinvestigator.com/2010/05/28/golf-good-walk/
Excellent puzzle!!!

Today's puzzle was a lark, full of wonderful wordplay. Once I saw the first triplet, it all filled in quickly. I tied my best time for a Tuesday to the second, which is the first occurrence of this! The Mark Twain quip about golf appears in crosswords frequently, and indeed, that's how I know of it.
Fun puzzle and as soon as I got the first theme entry, the other two were a breeze, leading me to beat my average for Tuesday by a few minutes!

What a delightful diversion.

I‚Äôve always appreciated a good dose of whimsy, and I am fast becoming a Kathy Lowden fan! I also think I know why Dolly was dilly-dallying: She was dotingly doodling her oodles of poodles! (It‚Äôs all connected.)
Whimsical and amusing!  A pleasant and appreciated departure from the news articles.  Thanks!
Enjoyed this puzzle and its theme. Did get stuck for a few minutes having an E instead of a Y for Hasty/Lacy (Haste/Lace). Still kept up my streak but a little slower than usual for a Tuesday.
Lovely, breezy Tuesday. A complete joy. Thank you.

I grew up singing that paddywack song, Wore thongs before the word morphed into a bikini bottom that shows off your derrier. Had to stop dallying, and clean my room. My kids played beer pong in college. This was down and around and over the rainbow, no penny backs, easy-peasy. Thanks

Sotto Voce, I do hope you're getting royalties!!  ;-)

 I got it completely off crosses but I like that APE was clued differently than it usually is as a form of imitating someone. Not sure why, but that usage of the word is irksome to me. No big deal but I appreciated today's clue. 

Nice, light-hearted puzzle that felt fresh. Enjoyed the fun theme. 

I wish we were still ASEA. Life moves so fast... it feels like our cruise vacation last week was already months ago. What I'd give for a FLIPFLOPFLAP right about now...  ;-)

Others have probably noted that Twain almost certainly wasn't the source of the golf quote. The original speaker is lost to the mists of time. It had various attributions beginning in the 1890s and the first attribution to Twain was in the 1940s.
First Tuesday we ever solved without looking anything up!! 18 mins, too. Seems almost too easy for a Tuesday then... or maybe we're finally getting smarter
Puzzles as good as this one deserve, with harder clueing, a later day in the week, IMHO.
Sam, I think Twain's memorable quote was referencing what a completely frustrating experience golf can be for beginners! That frustration is what ruins an otherwise lovely walk.
You should credit W S Gilbert for that tongue-twister.
This was very cute! I really loved it!
Cute and quick
A lot of fun! The rhymes made me smile -- esp. after Sunday's super un-fun slog
@Steve L 6- nope, definitely nope.

Steve,

He has two Super Bowl rings. 
He is a quarterback.

The clue writer may have misunderstood, 
but nevertheless the clue is not incorrect.


And, left over from another earlier puzzle, 
it did not require use of the rebus function.

@Steve L 
Likewise, Jim McMahon has two SB rings but I don't think anyone thinks he "won" the one with the Packers.

Steve,

I understand SIMMS did not cause the second win; if he had been a defensive lineman could you not say he won two Super Bowls? I understand what you are saying about the win stat, but are you also saying only a QB can actually be a winner?

@Steve L 
I got 64D with one crossing, and I‚Äôm only 35. Then again, my grandfather worked on Madison Avenue, and I grew up with walls adorned with lots of ancient framed ad prints he or his firm had worked on in that had been packed and moved across the country when I was a baby. Or maybe I‚Äôve encountered the slogan in a Sinclair Lewis novel, or something.

@Steve L - The ARK clue was "large boats" so the ARKs in the synagogues are excluded by the clue, unless they are large boats. 

Those who objected made a valid point.

CaptainQ, Synagogues are excluded by the clue, but the plural for large boats is valid: "a boat or ship held to resemble that in which Noah and his family were preserved from the Flood" https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ark

@Barry Ancona 

I'm saying you can't claim to win a game you didn't play in (and I believe wasn't even on the roster for).

He was a Super Bowl champion because he was on the team that season.  He played most of the season until he was injured and help put the team into playoff contention.  (He had a 12-2 record when he was injured.)

The clue didn't say he was on two Super Bowl-winning teams; it said he won two Super Bowls.  I would allow "won two Super Bowl rings", but he didn't win that game.  Jeff Hostetler did, as did the rest of those who were on the field.

(Most significantly, Scott Norwood won it for the Giants.  He was the Buffalo kicker who missed a would-be winning chip shot field goal with  0:08 left in the game.  But he didn't get a ring.)

@CaptainQuahog 

I thought I made it clear I understood that.  But Barry is right, as much as I hate to admit it.

@Steve L

Phil ___, QB who won two Super Bowls with the Giants

This is a gray area. To a football fan, if you say, "quarterback Fred Smith won two Super Bowls" it would definitely mean he started in and won both. The quarterback is special because fans use it all the time to compare them. I didn't look it up but there are probably some quarterbacks who were on multiple winning rosters but fans wouldn't call them multiple Super Bowl winners. That's reserved for the legends like Tom Brady, who won seven. 

On the other hand I would say most(?) crossword solvers aren't this deeply into football and might not be aware of this nuance.

I'd say the clue isn't wrong, but could be polished uo a bit to make everyone happy.

@Mr Dave 

SIMMS had a season-ending injury in Week 14 and wasn't on the eligible roster for the Super Bowl.  Was he there that day?  I think so.  Does that mean he won the game?

Or are you saying it in the sense that you, sitting in your living room in SoCal, might say that "we" won if you were rooting for the Rams and they were successful?

To me, this one is clear cut.  SIMMS wasn't the backup or the third-string.  He didn't win that second Super Bowl.

But the Giants did beat Tom Brady and the Patriots twice, and both times, it was with Eli Manning.  With our 2-12 this year, it's comforting to think back on that.

@Striker 

Ha! Thank you! I appreciate not having to be up on stage again, fumbling for my speech. üòä

@sotto voce 

No pressure, just go on being you.  The awards are just something your agent will use for your next contract negotiation and will take care of themselves.

@Warren 

My agent just dropped me for not agreeing to legally change my name to sotto voce. 
He held up the print NYT to my face and, exasperated, slapped the back of his hand across it repeatedly and yelled, "Look!Look!"

He argued that a second appearance here was proof of how much farther I'd go in life. :-)
@Katrina S. Well done!
@G that‚Äôs funny!  I don‚Äôt get it but to each their own!

@Pani Korunova 

No, no.  Corbin is quite right.  The whole point of Twain's observation is that what could be an enjoyable walk through grass fields and hills is "spoiled" by the pointless and monotonous activity of ponderously aiming and chasing and thwacking and retrieving golf balls.  He doesn't appear to value the golf part at all, whether or not it's frustrating.  You obviously disagree.


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@B 

I'm with Pani on this.  

The "spoilage" occurs when the golfer's planned approach to success on a hole is shattered by poor execution of a shot or two.

This is best explained by a Scotsman:

 In proving foresight may be vain:
The best laid schemes o‚Äô Mice an‚Äô Men
          Gang aft agley,
An‚Äô lea‚Äôe us nought but grief an‚Äô pain,
          For promis‚Äôd joy!      ---Robert Burns

Fortunately, that grief and pain can be swept from memory by a couple of pars and a rare birdie scored in a beautiful setting among good company.

@Al  in Pittsburgh 

Funny, I'm with B on this.

Mark Twain had a notoriously wry sense of humor, so I can absolutely imagine him mocking the game and sneering at golfers.
My take, anyway.
@Pani Korunova it appears that the phrase was well known prior to Twain. https://quoteinvestigator.com/2010/05/28/golf-good-walk/

The walk is spoiled when you introduce the frustration that playing golf brings.  For anyone who has played golf, I submit that more would agree that golf can be frustrating rather than monotonous.  All those bent golf clubs were not caused by monotony.

@Jim 


Either way, monotony vs. frustration, and regardless of the quote origin, all besides the point I think.  What would be a nice walk is spoiled by something less enjoyable than the walk.  (I don't think the joke is served well by assuming the person set out to play golf.)

And obvs this is all very important.  :)


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@B 

When the answer was OBVS (on 10/31), one commenter said "OBVi felt way more OBVi than OBVS".  Someone else said, "I put OBVI instead of OBVS, both of which are valid slang."

Anyway, OBVI has appeared 5 times, and OBVS jus the once.  

And how is OBVS easier to say than "obvious"?

@Steve L 

SRSLY?

@Bill in Yokohama 

Who do you think you are, Barry?

@Steve L 

It is easier to say.  It's close to one syllable where obvi clearly is not.

Before posting above I did a couple of quick searches to be sure.  Not one first page search hit for "obvi" referred to a texting abbreviation.  Many did for a search on "obvs".  It's also clearly, to me, of one and the same form as other teen coinages such as "suss" and "adorbs" and "totes".  Whilst "obvi" is useful for basically nothing and has none of the arguable charm of the other.

As a side note, "LOL" has always bothered me in all forms, since it's nearly always a lie.  Better now, Andrzej?  We're back on hostile terms.  ;)


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@B 

I often laugh out loud, so when I lol, I lol indeed. Friends again? ü§£

@B 

First of all, the clue said "informally".  Nothing about texting abbreviations.  I wouldn't know what abbrs. are common among the texterati, because I, and the people I text with, generally use normal English.

Secondly, your search method is flawed.  If you search "obvi", you're going to get hits for a line of beauty products first.  "Obvs" doesn't have any other use that would bump the texting abbr. off the first page.

Try searching "obvi texting" and you'll find it exists.

@Steve L 

I used "texting abbreviation" as shorthand - I find there are zero language / slang / "informal" references on the first 3 pages of my search hits, and only ONE in the next SIXTEEN pages!  That is a remarkably low profile regardless of some random brand name also using the spelling.

If it's popular, people are doing a really good job of hiding it.  Shrug emoji. :)

@Andrzej , yes we can be friends again.... But it doesn't feel right does it?  ;)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@sotto voce 

Thanks.
@john ezra Kava can be purchased on Amazon or Whole Foods and pretty much any health food store, so not so arcane.
@john ezra I had the K first on the gray wolf prey clue and was wondering whether gray wolves lived in the Himalayas, and if so,  whether they could take down a yaK!

@john ezra 

"Last time I'll ever call anything arcane around here!"  Even if it is actually arcane?  Seems like an overreaction.  

BTW, there is a kava bar in my town, but I would be surprised if there were many more in the state of North Carolina.  

And when did people get too lazy to call it kava kava?  Probably around the same time mahi-mahi just became mahi.

@sotto voce 

That will be the day when my name/handle features in a NYT puzzle ü§£.

@Andrzej 

All it would take is if your president invades Russia or does something equally newsworthy.  After all, many Americans now know the name Volodymyr pretty well.
He has been breaking the Polish Constitution for almost 10 years now so I'd rather my name were not clued using that guy. I'm very glad he will be out of office in a few months.

@Andrzej 

Too funny. 
My own real name has shown up but with two N's instead of just one, so it didn't quite cut it. 
That's the thing with having a foreign spelling and pronunciation, we'll never find our likeness in the NYT xword, so 
I'll admit to getting kind of psyched for sotto voce showing up ‚Äì I felt seen! üòÇ

@Mean Old Lady 

I'm totally with you on that one.

Whenever I went on a golfing trip with my ex, you could find him on the green and me in the hotel spa or the village nearby. 
That's how we made it a grand time for both of us!

@G 

You're the sweetest.
.
.
.
.

@dutchiris ,

I wish I could give you a few recommendations,  great comment.

@dutchiris Agreed. But I think those who talk about "cheating" may be referring also to the puzzle as being a challenge between the constructor and the solver. That is an interesting idea would that we knew the constructor was using only their own knowledge. But it is no secret that constructors have access to this thing called the internet which contains essentially the whole of humankind's data. I have argued before that there should be a "special" day in the NYT's puzzle week (maybe rolled it into Thursday or better Monday), where the constructor declares they have not used any outside resources in the construction of the puzzle.
@dutchiris applause, applause (standing ovation)

@dutchiris 

I think what is meant as helpful advice directed only at those who have a goal of solving without outside help is often misinterpreted as criticism of those who do not have that goal.  Obviously, there is nothing wrong with either, but feelings seem to get ruffled when trying to help the people with the former goal.

Super8ing,

Should a jig-saw puzzle, or an intricate puzzle-box, be made only with the hands, using no wood-working tools? And should a Monday puzzle only be considered fair if it is constructed in under, let‚Äôs say, 15 minutes? Should a hedge-maze maker not be allowed to use shears?

As has been noted here before, the point is not what tools the puzzle maker uses, but rather how skillfully they apply the tools at their disposal to make a puzzle that is both challenging and fair for the solvers. 

The constructors are not cheating, that much is certain. And neither are we (unless we break rules we‚Äôve agreed to).

@dutchiris 
I thought that Will Shortz had "the last word" quite a long while back:  it's your puzzle; solve it any way you want to!  (Or words to that effect.)  Words to live by!

It's a personal choice.  I don't think my (unassisted) solve is any more honorable or laudable that someone else's Google-assisted completion.  I'm old, I write, I read a lot, I enjoy struggling over a puzzle, and I don't successfully complete them all.  Oh, well.  
We don't need no stinkin' badges!

Given how many reccos @dutchiris got, I know I am going to get clobbered, but I will state my opinion anyway:

I realize cheating has a negative connotation, but it is also just a euphemism for those that get outside help to get the gold star.  I think it becomes actual cheating when one starts keeping score, while getting outside help.  To me  completion times, streaks, etc. are meaningless if one used outside help.  I'm fine  with others getting outside help, it was not that long ago that I was doing the same, but don't pretend your streak or completion times actually matter.

Jim,

But pretending is fun, and important.

Like pretending money has value, or painted lines will keep cars in their lanes, or crossword competitions matter‚Ä¶ ever.

"...don't pretend your streak or completion times actually matter."


Jim,

Matter to whom? If I look up answers I don't know, the variance in my completion times isn't allowed to mean anything to me? SRSLY? 

Yes, I would appreciate it when people post their solve times or streak lengths if they would also note what they do in order to solve the puzzles. Context is important, but the data does matter.

@Jim 

Your opinion doesn't matter.

@Mean Old Lady 
I'm old (90), and I too enjoy struggling over a puzzle. I used to look up obscure islands in the Ionian Sea and drummers in rap bands I've never heard of, but In the past couple of years I upped the bar to stay with the puzzle, mano a mano, until the crosses still refused to reveal the unknowns; then I come to the column or ask Dr. Google if the puzzle is still not done.  

I ended a streak with last Sunday's puzzle, not because I didn't see where the painters were missing (I put them in rebus-style).  I took the painters out and left the letter where they completed the fill, put them back as rebuses. Nothing worked, because that wasn't where the error was.  I didn't know the slang FEM until I came to the column, but by then the puzzle was such a mess that I just gave up.

To some, my badge may seem tarnished from "cheating" (a pejorative word any way you want to cut it), but as you say, we don't need no stinkin' badgles anyway.

@Andrzej 

OK, I deserved that because my last sentence -- "but don't pretend your streak or completion times actually matter" -- is too harsh.  What I mean is, you can't compare a streak achieved by outside help to the same length streak achieved without outside help.  Same for completion times.  They are just not the same thing.  So I am not understanding what is the point of keeping score when you have gotten outside help.

@Jim 

But if that individual's personal baseline already includes allowing such cheats, then of course the stats are valid for that person.

@Steve L 

Interesting little rabbit hole I just plumbed based on your Food Lion comment.  I knew that the Lion part was almost accidental, since they changed their signage and it was cheap to change the original letters around.  However, I could have sworn that (a) the original name was Food Land and that (b) they changed it as a direct result of the embarrassing ABC report that they used bleach to resell old rotted meat.  What Los Wikipedias are telling me is that (a) the original name was Food Town and (b) they changed it before that report and (c) ABC's report may, or may not have been fraudulent.  But since the primary source they link on the "innocent" side is a harsh and particularly axe grindey screed at "Accuracy in Media" I think it's safe to continue to think of Food Lion as the Bleached Meat company, after all.
